post.author: bpanjavan
post.title: ASP.NET Data Binding Review
post.content:
I’m about to do a post on Silverlight 2-way data binding.  But to know where you’re going you need to know where you’ve been.   This post is a review of ASP.NET data binding in ASP.NET 2.0 / 3.5. 

Following are a few examples of different data binding scenarios.  I’ve posted the entire demo page here.

For most of them, I’m using a strongly typed collection of my own Person class.  See the class and method to get the collection below:



 

For the first 3 I use a GridView data control.  For the 4th I use a DataList.

1.)    The simple case.  In the example below, I get the collection, set the DataSource property, then call DataBind().



The GridView control is populated with the data from my collection.



2.)    Manipulate the data.  In this case, we set the DataSource property, but then we manipulate the data before calling DataBind().  Our manipulation is simple.  We zero out everyone’s age before calling DataBind().



The GridView control contains our data AFTER we manipulated it, because that’s when we called DataBind().



3.)    Manipulate the data AFTER.  In this case, we call DataBind() on the collection, THEN manipulate the data by zeroing out everyone’s age.



The result is that the GridView displays the original data prior to manipulation.  The important thing to realize here is that calling DataBind does a one-time snapshot of the data in its current state.



4.)    Try it with a DataList instead.  This scenario is the same as #3.  The only difference is that we use a DataList instead of a GridView. 



But the result is the same.  The DataList data contains the snapshot prior to manipulation of the collection.



But DataBinding is not limited to data collection controls like the Repeater / DataList / GridView / FormView / DetailsView.  ASP.NET controls can have a property set through a DataSource expression.  Then calling DataBind() on the control binds control property with the current value of the DataSource.

In the example below, two textboxes are given a declarative DataSource reference to the same variable from the code behind page.



We set the value of the rating variable, then call DataBind() on the first textbox.  Then we set the value of the rating variable again, then call DataBind() on the second textbox.



Result



We can conclude the following characteristics of ASP.NET DataBinding:

·         DataBinding is one-way, from a source variable / collection to the respective control

·         DataBinding is a “snap-shot” of the data at the time DataBind() is called.  It is NOT a real-time reflection of the current state of the data.

 Next time I'll cover 2-way Data Binding in Silverlight 3...

comment.author: import vcard files, vcard
comment.content: This is getting a bit more subjective, but I much prefer the Zune Marketplace. The interface is colorful, has more flair, and some cool features like 'Mixview' that let you quickly see related albums, songs, or other users related to what you're listening to. Clicking on one of those will center on that item, and another set of "neighbors" will come into view, allowing you to navigate around exploring by similar artists, songs, or users. Speaking of users, the Zune "Social" is also great fun, letting you find others with shared tastes and becoming friends with them. You then can listen to a playlist created based on an amalgamation of what all your friends are listening to, which is also enjoyable. Those concerned with privacy will be relieved to know you can prevent the public from seeing your personal listening habits if you so choose.
